conclusion: Understanding the relationship between acceleration, velocity, and time.
Graph shows acceleration starts at 2 m/s² at t=0, decreases to 0 m/s² at t=2 s, and then to -2 m/s² at t=4 s.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity; slope of acceleration-time graph indicates velocity change.
At t=0, acceleration is +2 m/s², object speeds up in positive direction.
From t=2 s to t=4 s, acceleration is negative, object slows down in positive direction.
Velocity increases from t=0 to t=2 s and decreases from t=2 s to t=4 s; maximum velocity at t=2 s.
Area under acceleration-time graph from t=0 to t gives change in velocity.
Calculate velocity at t=2 s using area under graph: Area = (1/2) * 2 s * 2 m/s² = 2 m/s.
Calculate change in velocity from t=2 s to t=4 s: Area = (1/2) * 2 s * (-2 m/s²) = -2 m/s.
Velocity at t=4 s is 0 m/s; maximum velocity at t=2 s is +2 m/s.
Reaffirm maximum velocity occurs at t=2 s.
Consider possibility of velocity increasing beyond t=2 s; negative acceleration prevents this.
Final conclusion: object's velocity is at its maximum at t=2 s.
